Memory use (and traffic to disk) is more a function of the
number of hosts/queues that have been discovered or active,
than of the total number of URLs discovered or crawled. So
any 'broader' crawls will strain resources more than
'narrower' ones with a smaller or fixed number of hosts
of interest.

Your machine may be swapping heavily. Things to check:

  - Does 'top' show swap in use?
  - How does your configured max heap and current heap size
    compare with RAM? (Max heap should be 25% or more smaller
  - Do the 'si' and 'so' columns in 'vmstat 2'
    (sample every 2 seconds) show activity?

Separately from OS virtual memory, the new BDB/soft-reference
mechanism for 'paging' per-host/per-queue data out when not in
immediate use could theoretically reach some excessive IO states
in low-memory conditions. This would be more likely if you weren't
using the 'hold-queues' setting and were instead round-robinning
among all queues in a big crawl.

- Gordon @ IA
